body: Raising priority to P1. This prevents us from removing NPN support and offering a migration path to users building on platforms with only NPN support. Removing the check for NPN and only checking for ALPN will simplify the problem to rebuilding with the latest (released) codebase.
Also this would need a backport to 1.12 /cc @mehrdada
@hsaliak 1.11 or 1.12? 1.12 has not been cut yet due to pending blockers.
@mehrdada, this hasn't been fixed either. So if it isn't in time for the 1.12 branch cut, then we should still backport it.
@ejona86 If it is urgent and the fix is straightforward, then we should tag it RELEASE BLOCKER. We are waiting on a couple other PRs at this point.
P0 is here different from our normal definition of P0 (fix it today!), so I'm a bit confused whether I should remove the P1 label.

OpenSSL starts to support ALPN on 1.0.2. Can we further improve that if customer uses anything below OpenSSL 1.1, we will enable BoringSSL automatically? This will save us a lot of troubles supporting legacy OpenSSL.

Suggest keeping this P1.. its a small fix that should be doable.
@nicolasnoble would be the most knowledgeable person to comment on @jiangtaoli2016 's comment, but I see that openssl 1.1 was just released on Aug 2016, so it may be too high a bar?

OpenSSL 1.0.2 released on Jan 2015.
https://www.openssl.org/news/openssl-1.0.2-notes.html

If we can make sure gRPC only use OpenSSL 1.0.2+ API, at least we do not need to support ancient OpenSSL 0.9.x.
Ping @murgatroid99 - this has an impact on nodejs, because they have an embedded OpenSSL inside the node runtime, that we currently rely on to exist.
All of the version of Node we support have at least OpenSSL 1.0.2h
Removing RELEASE BLOCKER label as we can't wait longer to cut the branch. We can backport later.
RELEASE BLOCKER should be that it blocks the release, not the branch cut.
Since this is not a regression, if it takes too long to fix, I think we should still ship. However, it's good for that label to remain for motivational purposes. :)
That should probably be discussed some with @hsaliak. Without this fix clients we be breaking as servers drop NPN support.

@nicolasnoble is there any hope we can get a fix in the next couple days? If not, I think I should ship 1.12 packages and we backport the fix to the 1.12.x branch (as it mainly affects build from source, this should be fine)

I want to add a caveat to my previous comment. In some cases users install Node from a package manager, and because those generally do not allow republication of OpenSSL, those version of Node use whatever version of OpenSSL is present on the system. We saw this cause a problem in #9887, where the system OpenSSL was too old to support ALPN.

If we remove ALPN support, there will be a couple of problems with continuing to support those users. First, when building the library, the Node headers include the OpenSSL headers, so the BoringSSL headers conflict with that. On Windows we have solved that by explicitly deleting those OpenSSL headers in our build script, but that is not a good solution for a user installing the library on their system. I don't know how to solve this, and if we make this change without solving it this will break those users.

In addition, the solution we provide to those users was a build flag `--grpc_alpn`. Setting that to false disables ALPN support in gRPC. If we make this change, and we want to avoid breaking those users' workflow, we will probably have to put "built with BoringSSL" behind the flag `--grpc_alpn=false` even though that's not semantically accurate.
Or in other words, this would result in a semver breaking change for some node users.
@nicolasnoble @murgatroid99 Do we have a decision on how/whether to proceed with this?

We're going to need to do same per-language wrangling. I've updated the main issue comment with some newer details.

We're going to try to do all the _easy_ stuff for the release. Any hard cases can be forked off into separate issues or similar.

@nicolasnoble, @nathanielmanistaatgoogle, @apolcyn, @murgatroid99, @muxi, and @stanley-cheung, please see the initial comment in this issue. You are included for your respective languages. Feel free to "reassign" by updating the initial comment and pinging the new "assignee."

This is a blocker for the release. We're wanting to get the low-hanging fruit for this release and get an idea of our status. Any bigger work items will be delayed.
PHP includes boringssl in the PECL extension source distribution.
Ruby packages use boringssl (they use the `EMBED_OPENSSL=true` grpc Makefile setting).

ObjC uses Cocoapods to grab dependencies. It downloads and builds a version of boringssl corresponding to the commit that core uses (in `third_party/boringssl`).

We do have one or two users that manually switched to openssl because boringssl conflicts with openssl in another of their dependencies (see #6111).
@jtattermusch can you confirm for C#? (I think that C# doesn't necessarily include boringssl).
Ping @jtattermusch, @nathanielmanistaatgoogle.
for C#, boringssl is always embedded in grpc_csharp_ext library distributed with the NuGet packages.
Is this actively worked on? Should we expect this to be fixed by next release date (09/10)?
